question: Oh, actually, Charlie, those two are herbivores. They wouldn't be interested in fighting each other. But these... See, these are carnivores. And this one here -- see its claws -- this one here uses its claws to gouge at the throat of its opponent
answer: Uh, Alan?

question: Hmm?
answer: He's three. Why don't you wait till he's a little older?

question: Oh, right. Happy dinosaurs.
answer: That must be Mark. Mark, were back here! Good day? Mark, this is Alan Grant.

question: What's my name? Come on, Jack, say it. Is my name Alan? Say my name. He used to know me.
answer: Sorry, Alan it's been six years. Yes. Great. So, Mark's working at the State Department now.

question: Really? What do you do there? Indeed.
answer: So what are you working on now?

question: We have a new site in Montana. At least until the money runs out.
answer: Anything good?

question: Raptors, mostly.
answer: My favorite.

question: You remember the sounds they made?
answer: I try not to.

question: We've done cranial scans, and raptors actually had a quite sophisticated resonating chamber. I have a theory that their ability to vocalize is the key to their social intelligence. The way they can work together as a team.
answer: You think they could talk to each other?

question: To a degree we never imagined.
answer: You taught him that. Good luck with the fund raising.

question: It was never easy, but before Jurassic Park, you could find money. Somewhere. Now fossils are out. Everyone wants to see a real live dinosaur.
answer: Times change Alan. But you're the still the best. I mean that.

question: The last of my breed. I'd better get going.
answer: Let me know if I can help, Alan. Youre bad about asking for help, but please ask me. Anything, anytime.

question: Okay. Goodbye, Ellie.
answer: Goodbye, Alan. When I met you, I thought that one day millions of years ago, all the dinosaurs became extinct. Wiped out. But you told me otherwise. When conditions changed, dinosaurs changed. They became other things. They evolved.

question: A well-accepted theory.
answer: Alan don't be afraid to evolve.

question: You need to go slowly. See, just take it little at a time. Technically, it's all rock. The calcium in the bones is replaced during fossilization. But you can feel the difference. See? Rough, smooth. Rough, smooth. Dr. Grant!
answer: Mr. Brennan.

question: How was your trip? Profitable?
answer: We'll be broke in four weeks.

question: Three weeks. I had to rent some equipment.
answer: You rented an automated litter box.

question: It's a rapid prototyper. I feed in the scan data from the raptor skull, than the computer breaks it into thousands of slices which this thing prints, one layer on top of the other. It's the future of paleontology.
answer: Not if it can't dig.

question: I give you a raptor's resonating chamber.
answer: Absolutely not.

question: They're here.
answer: What? Yes? What can I do for you, Mr. Kirby?

question: What? Yes? What can I do for you, Mr. Kirby?
answer: Well sir, I am a great admirer of yours, and I have an extremely interesting proposition to discuss. Would you let my wife and I take you to have dinner tonight? Our treat.

question: You know, I've been traveling and I'm very tired. Maybe some other time.
answer: I guarantee it'll be worth your while.

question: It's be my pleasure.
answer: First off let me say as a dinosaur enthusiasts, Amanda and I have admired your work for years.

question: Even with what I pay you, you could get a better bag.
answer: No way. This is lucky. Couple years ago some buddies and I went hang gliding off these cliffs in New Zealand. Updraft sent me right into the side. BOOM!

question: That does sound lucky.
answer: It was this strap alone that saved my life. Got caught on a rock as I was falling.

question: Reverse-Darwinism. Survival of the most idiotic.
answer: Listen Alan, I really appreciate you bringing me along.

question: The bones will be there when we get back. That's the nice thing about them. They never run away. And besides, you got me into this. I don't intend to be alone with these people.
answer: So how do you know the Kirby's?

question: So how do you know the Kirby's?
answer: Through our church.

question: What Religion?
answer: Uhthe one that worships God and believes in being Good.

question: Amanda, Honey! Dr. Grant says it's a bad idea!
answer: What?

question: He says it's a bad idea!
answer: What's a bad idea?

question: Excellent. Sorry.
answer: Nothing you haven't seen before. How much weight have you lost?

question: Twenty, twenty-fire pounds. I've been swimming at the Y.
answer: You hate to swim.

question: People change. You look good.
answer: So do you.

question: How would you classify it?
answer: Obviously a superpredator. Suchimimus. that snout.

question: They never got that big.
answer: Baryonyx?

question: Not with that sail. Spinosaurus Aegypticus.
answer: I don't remember that on InGen's list.

question: That's because it wasn't on their list. Who knows what else they were up to?
answer: So Mr. Kirby, tell me, when you climbed K2, did you base camp at 25- or 30,000 feet?

question: Stop that. Dr. Grant says this is dangerous territory.
answer: Well we should split up or something. We can cover twice the area.

question: No, Dr. Grant says...
answer: Dr. Grant says this, Dr. Grant says that...

question: Well what's the use of hiring an expert if your not going to listen to him?
answer: Because "Dr. Grant" isn't looking for Eric. Dr. Grant is looking for the coast.

question: Fine...and when the Tricyclatops comes after you, don't come crying to me.
answer: Oh, don't worry about that.

question: What?
answer: Nothing.

question: What did you say?
answer: Nothing.

question: What did you say!
answer: Just drop it Paul!

question: Ben!
answer: Unclip the line! Hand on! Hang on buddy! Are you ok, buddy?

question: I don't know. I think so.
answer: We're okay. It's going to be okay. Here, get ready. I'm going to unhook you.

question: I'm all right
answer: We're going to get out of this, pal.

question: What does that mean? What are you saying? God damn you, Billy. It means, "Give us the egg," doesn't it? "We want the egg." Eric... Eric, your parents are both here.
answer: In Costa Rica?

question: On the island.
answer: They'll never make it. I mean, they can't manage when the cable goes out.

question: You'd be surprised what people can do when they have too.
answer: You're Alan Grant, aren't you? I read both of your books.

question: Which one do you prefer?
answer: The first one. Before you where on the island. You liked dinosaurs back then.

question: Back then, they hadn't tried to eat me.
answer: When InGen cleared out, they left a lot of stuff behind.

question: Any weapons, radios?
answer: Found this, but the battery's dead.

question: It's a wonder you aren't. I'm amazed, Eric. I barely lasted 30 hours. You lasted eight weeks.
answer: Is that all it's been? I thought it was longer.

question: The important thing is we both made it. That's something we have in common. Did you read Malcolm's book?
answer: Yeah.

question: What did you think?
answer: I dunno. I mean, it was kind of preachy. Chaos-this, chaos-that. And like, to me, the guy seemed kind of high on himself.

question: Well Dr. Grant isn't here, so we're going to have to figure out what to do ourselves.
answer: I just want you know, Amanda. It's not your fault what happened.

question: Well what?
answer: Well damn it. I don't speak ill of the dead. What I'm trying to say is, its was just a crazy accident. The exact same thing could have happened if he was with me. You can't go beating yourself up about it.

question: This wouldn't happen if he was with you. I mean, you drive five miles below the speed limit. I totaled three cars in fives years.
answer: That one time was just the bumper.

question: He would have been, safe. Completely, entirely, suffocatingly safe. I would have him to see more of the world than Enid, Oklahoma. I wanted to see more of the world than Enid, Oklahoma. And so yes, it's my fault that this happened. I'm sorry that you have to be here.
answer: I'm not sorry at all.

question: Know what this is?
answer: A raptor claw. I use to have one. A fossil.

question: Mine's new.
answer: How much of this island have you explored?

question: I stayed pretty close to the compound, Figured if anyone came to look for me, that's where they'd start.
answer: We need to head for the coast.

question: Are you sure?
answer: Why?

question: I don't know. I don't have it with me.
answer: When did you have it last?

question: I don't remember
answer: Think.

question: The plane. I got a call on the plane, put it in my coat pocket, and...
answer: What?...WHAT!?

question: We need to keep moving.
answer: Alan, I want to tell you that I'm so sorry about the...

question: Billy, I can't talk to you now.
answer: Please, okay? Just yell at me. Call me an idiot. An asshole. Stupid. Tell me I screwed up because I know I did. I thought if we could get a raptor back to the mainland, we could get serious money for it. Enough to fund the digging for 10 years. More. Whatever it took. You have to believe me. I did it with the best intentions.

question: It's no use, Dr. Grant. No use. My own kid was right in front of me and I didn't do a damn thing.
answer: You couldn't have made that jump.

question: I should have tried. It should have been me on that beach back there, not Billy.
answer: How would you have helped Eric? He needs you, Paul. He needs us.

question: He could have died.
answer: But he didn't. And neither did you. And I'm glad about that.

question: Do you have any kids?
answer: No. Although I've studied them in the wild. I have a theory that there's two kinds of boys. Those who want to be astronomers and those who want to be astronauts.

question: I want to be an astronaut.
answer: See, I was the opposite. I never understood why anyone would want to go into space. It's so dangerous. You do one thing wrong and you're dead. The astronomer -- or the paleontologist -- get to study these amazing things from a place of complete safety. And truthfully, everything you really need to learn, you can learn it from the ground.

question: But then you never get to go in space.
answer: Exactly. The difference between imagining how things might be and seeing how they really are. To be able to touch them. That's what Billy wanted to do. Keep quiet. Find it before it stops ringing!

question: Pick up! Pick up!
answer: Hewwo?

question: Charlie? Charlie. Get your mother. Right away! Charlie? Are you there?
answer: Hewwo?

question: Charlie! It's the dinosaur man! Go get mommy, okay?
answer: Okay.

question: We have to keep looking for Dad. We have to.
answer: I know. I know. I want to look for him too.

question: then we should...
answer: Let me tell you a few things about you Dad, okay? He's very very very clever, very very brave, and he loves you ever very much.

question: He loves you too.
answer: Okay. He loves us very very much. And I know that right now more than anything, your Dad would want to know that we're safe. Okay? We're going to get out of this, and everything's going to be all right, I promise.

question: The lady you called, how do you know she can help us?
answer: She's the one person I could always count on. And she's saved me more times than she realizes. I owe her everything. It's strikes me now I never told her that.

question: You should.
answer: You're right. Eric, do you know what happened to the boat? that brought you here? Why did it crash?

question: No. I couldn't see.
answer: Do me a favor. Go back to your parents for a minute, would you? They look worried.
